Tests to compare covariance matrices

Source: vignettes/Tests_Sigmas.Rmd
Tests_Sigmas.Rmd
library(stests)

Introduction

Let 𝐗1i,𝐗2i,…,𝐗Nii\mathbf{X}_{1i}, \mathbf{X}_{2i}, \ldots, \mathbf{X}_{N_i i} be a random sample from the population Np(𝛍g,𝚺g)N_p(\boldsymbol{\mu}_g, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_g) indexed by i=1,2,…,gi = 1,2,\ldots,g. In other words, we have gg samples as follows

𝐗11,𝐗21,…,𝐗N11𝐗12,𝐗22,…,𝐗N22⋮𝐗1g,𝐗2g,…,𝐗Ngg \begin{matrix} \mathbf{X}_{11}, \mathbf{X}_{21}, \ldots, \mathbf{X}_{N_1 1} \\ \mathbf{X}_{12}, \mathbf{X}_{22}, \ldots, \mathbf{X}_{N_2 2} \\ \vdots \\ \mathbf{X}_{1g}, \mathbf{X}_{2g}, \ldots, \mathbf{X}_{N_g g} \end{matrix}

It is not necessary to have equal NiN_i. The main objective in this vignette is to use test to study the following hypothesis.

H0:Σ1=Σ2=⋯=Σg=Σ H_{0}: \Sigma_{1} = \Sigma_{2} = \cdots = \Sigma_{g} = \Sigma

HA:at least one Σ is different H_{A}: \text{at least one } \Sigma \text{ is different}

Box-M test

Developed by Freddy Hernandez, Olga Usuga, Valentina Garcia, Jean Paul Piedrahita.
